revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2012}} '''Jason Stephens''' is an [[Australia]]n actor and comedian. He was educated at [[Wesley College, Melbourne]] and signed up as a writer on the second season of the ABC comedy ''[[The D-Generation]]'' (1987), before graduating to the role of writer/performer on the latter years of D-Gen's Triple M radio show (1990–1992). Stephens also performed with [[Tony Martin (comedian)|Tony Martin]], [[Mick Molloy]] and John Harrison on the 1991 radio show ''Bulltwang'' and was a writer/performer on the D-Gen's subsequent TV venture, ''[[The Late Show (1990s Australian TV series)|The Late Show]]'' (1992–1993).<ref>[https://archive.is/20121202231033/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,22340210-5006022,00.html] </ref> Along with Mick Molloy, Stephens hosted the ''Late Show'' segment ''Muckrakers''. After ''The Late Show'' ended, Stephens became involved in other TV comedy programmes, including a stint as director on the [[Network Ten]] comedy ''Totally Full Frontal'' (1998). From 2004 - 2014 Stephens worked as the creative director for [[FremantleMedia|FremantleMedia Australia]], one of Australia's leading independent television production companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2014/05/jason-stephens-departs-fremantlemedia-australia.html|title=Jason Stephens departs FremantleMedia Australia|date=8 May 2014|website=Tvtonight.com.au|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref>
Stephens was the creator behind ''[[The Choir of Hard Knocks]]''; he was also involved in chronicling the choir for the documentary series of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.encoremagazine.com.au/articles/D8/0C0495D8.aspx/|title=Choir offers sanctuary from ‘Hard Knocks’|website=Encoremagazine.com.au|accessdate=2017-08-19}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He also produced ''[[The King (2007 film)|The King]]'', a telemovie based on the life of [[Graham Kennedy]]. ''The King'' won 3 [[Australian Film Institute Awards]] including Best Telefeature, Best Direction in a television drama and Best Actor in a television drama.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/awardcentral_article/VR1117977178.html?nav=news&categoryid=1983&cs=1|title=VR’s first stop won’t be at home|first=Matt|last=Rothman|date=8 March 1993|publisher=}}</ref>
Stephens also developed the satirical news show ''[[Newstopia]]'', starring [[Shaun Micallef]], which premiered in October 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.encoremagazine.com.au/articles/8D/0C05108D.aspx/|title=Micallef back to satirise news|website=Encoremagazine.com.au|accessdate=2017-08-19}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 2011, Stephens executive produced the TV series ''[[Killing Time (TV series)|Killing Time]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australiantelevision.net/killing-time/|title=Australian Television: Killing Time|website=Australiantelevision.net|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref> a ten-part crime drama which aired on [[TV1 (Australia)|TV1]]. ''Killing Time'' was nominated for Most Outstanding Drama and [[Diana Glenn]] was nominated for Most Outstanding Performance by an Actor - Female at the 2012 [[ASTRA Awards]].<ref name="imdb.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1683523/awards|title=Killing Time|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref>[[David Wenham]] won Most Outstanding Performance by an Actor - Male.<ref name="imdb.com"/> Both Glenn and Wenham were also nominated for a Silver Logie at the [[TV Week Logie Awards]] in 2012.
More recently, Stephens has executive produced the AACTA 2013 nominated mini series ''[[Devil's Dust]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2012/11/devils-dust.html|title=Devil’s Dust|date=5 November 2012|publisher=}}</ref> based on the life story of Asbestos campaigner Bernie Banton and aired on the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]. Devil's Dust was nominated for Best Telefeature or Mini Series at the 2013 [[AACTA Awards]] <ref name="aacta.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.aacta.org/winners-nominees/2nd-aacta-awards.aspx|title=AACTA Winners & Nominees|website=Aacta.org|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref> with [[Anthony Hayes (actor)|Anthony Hayes]] nominated for Best Lead Actor in a Television Drama.<ref name="aacta.org"/>
In addition to this, Stephens is the executive producer for ''[[Better Man (TV series)|Better Man]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1672772/SBS-returns-to-drama-with-new-series-Better-Man|title=SBS returns to drama with new series 'Better Man'|website=Sbs.com|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref> the 4-hour drama based on a true story, which was set to air in 2013 on [[Special Broadcasting Service]].
In February 2013, Stephens' prime time murder mystery, ''[[Mr & Mrs Murder]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mumbrella.com.au/ten-to-air-fremantlemedia-murder-mystery-drama-mr-mrs-murder-89503|title=Ten to air FremantleMedia murder mystery drama Mr & Mrs Murder - Mumbrella|date=4 May 2012|website=Mumbrella.com.au|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref> starring [[Shaun Micallef]]<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://ten.com.au/tvshows/mrandmrsmurder-about.htm|title=Tenplay|website=Ten.com.au|accessdate=2017-08-19}}</ref> and [[Kat Stewart]],<ref name="auto"/> aired on [[Network Ten]].
